segmentation module¶

class src.cyto.segmentation.Gate(segment, t, pd, gate, tight_gate, sample_num, ch_num, gate_num_in_sample, overall_indx_in_data=None)[source]¶

Bases: object

This is an abstraction class for a flow cytometry 1-D gate.

Parameters

  • segment – numpy.array(dtype=float), shape = [n, 1], An array containing original data (cells) of a particular segment/gate.

  • t – numpy.array(dtype=float), shape = [m, 1], An array that represents the x axis. (pdf represents the y axis)

  • pd – numpy.array(dtype=float), shape = [m, 1], An array which represents probability density function.

  • gate – obj:list: open-ended gate location.

  • tight_gate – list: tight gate location.

  • sample_num – int: the sample number of which this gate belongs to.

  • ch_num – int: the channel number of which this gate belongs to.

  • gate_num_in_sample – obj:int, gate number in sample.

  • overall_indx_in_data – obj:int, the overall index of a gate in the dataset.

Variables

  • seg_min – float, minimum value in segment.

  • seg_max – float, maximum value in segment.

  • location_group – int, the location group number this gate belongs to.

  • group_ref_score – float, the gate score as a reference for its own location group.

  • morphology_group – int, the morphology group number this gate belongs to.

  • is_location_reference – Bool `, if :obj:`True, the gate is the reference for its location group.

  • aligned_flag – :obj:`int `, flag indicating alignment status.

get_tight_gates(q=0.01)[source]¶

Returns tight location of gate based on the provided quantile

Parameters

q – float, quantile value.

Returns

  • a - float, left boundary.

  • b - float, right boundary.

get_tightened_segment(a=None, b=None)[source]¶

Get data of segment within the input bounds. Default behaviour returns segment within original tightened bounds.

Parameters

  • a – float, start location.

  • b – float, end location.

Returns

  • bounded_segment - numpy.array, 1-D array of data within the specified bound.

class src.cyto.segmentation.Sample(data, gates_per_channel, sample_num, gate_factor_q=0.04, area_threshold=0.005, kde_window=0.3, width_threshold=0.2, depth_threshold=0.2, verbose=True)[source]¶

Bases: object

This is an abstraction class for a flow cytometry sample. It houses the raw data and also allows several levels of manipulation such as having access to particular channel’s data, its probability density function and so forth. A sample is comprised of a number of channels. Each channel consists of a number of gates/segments.

Parameters

  • data – numpy.array(dtype=float), shape = [m, ch], A 2-D array containing the original data (rows = cells, columns = channels). m = number of cells, ch= number of channels.

  • gates_per_channel – numpy.array(dtype=int), shape = [ch, 1], A 1-D array containing the number of gates in each channel. A ‘-1’ entery means unspecified (Automatic Segmentation).

  • sample_num – int, sample number in dataset.

  • gate_factor_q – numpy.array(dtype=float), shape = [ch, 1], A 1-D array containing quantile value for each channel.

  • kde_window – numpy.array(dtype=float), shape = [ch, 1], A 1-D array containing Kernel Density Estimate window size for each channel. This determines how coarse or granular the estimated pdf is.

  • area_threshold – numpy.array(dtype=float), shape = [ch, 1], A 1-D array containing the minimum allowed AUC (ratio of cells) to be considered a proper segment/gate. Only required for watershed segmentation.

  • width_threshold – numpy.array(dtype=float), shape = [ch, 1], A 1-D array containing the minimum allowed width of the ravine between two segments/gates for the later to be considered a separate segment or an extension of the previous segment. Only required for watershed segmentation.

  • depth_threshold – numpy.array(dtype=float), shape = [ch, 1], A 1-D array containing the minimum allowed depth of the ravine between two segments/gates for the later to be considered a separate segment or an extension of the previous segment. Only required for watershed segmentation.

  • verbose – Bool, if True, prints all information about all gates in each channel in sample.

Variables

  • pdfs – dict(list), a dictionary of the following pair [x, probability density functions] with channel number as its key.

  • gates – dict(list(Gate)), a dictionary of lists of gates with channel number as its key.

  • num_ch – int, number of channels.

check_if_still_non_aligned(channel)[source]¶

Checks whether all gates in the provided channel have been aligned or not.

Parameters

channel – int, channel number.

Returns

Bool.

Returns

Bool.

resegment_ch(ch, kde_window=None, area_threshold=None, width_threshold=None, depth_threshold=None, init=False, verbose=True)[source]¶

Resegments channel based on new threshold values.

Parameters

  • ch – int, channel number.

  • kde_window – numpy.array(dtype=float), shape = [ch, 1], A 1-D array containing Kernel Density Estimate window size for each channel. This determines how coarse or granular the estimated pdf is.

  • area_threshold – numpy.array(dtype=float), shape = [ch, 1], A 1-D array containing the minimum allowed AUC (ratio of cells) to be considered a proper segment/gate. Only required for watershed segmentation.

  • width_threshold – numpy.array(dtype=float), shape = [ch, 1], A 1-D array containing the minimum allowed width of the ravine between two segments/gates for the later to be considered a separate segment or an extension of the previous segment. Only required for watershed segmentation.

  • depth_threshold – numpy.array(dtype=float), shape = [ch, 1], A 1-D array containing the minimum allowed depth of the ravine between two segments/gates for the later to be considered a separate segment or an extension of the previous segment. Only required for watershed segmentation.

  • init – Bool, if True, recomputes probability density function.

  • verbose – Bool, if True, prints all information about all gates in each channel in sample.

Parameters

  • index – int, gate index.

  • flag – int, alignment flag.

src.cyto.segmentation.convert_gates_to_watershed_lines(gates)[source]¶

Given a list of gates such as [[0,.5], [.5,1]] this method returns the following list of watershed lines [0, 0.5, 1].

Parameters

gates – list(list), len(gates) = m where m is the number of gates.

Return watershed_lines

list, len(watershed_lines) = m+1 where m is the number of watershed lines.

src.cyto.segmentation.convert_watershed_lines_to_gate(watershed_lines)[source]¶

Given watershed lines such as [0, 0.5, 1], this method returns the following list of gates [[0,.5], [.5,1]].

Parameters

watershed_lines – list, len(bounds) = m where m is the number of watershed lines.

Return gates

list(list), len(gates) = m-1 where m is the number of gates.

src.cyto.segmentation.get_watershed_lines_from_labeled_segs(seg_pdf, x)[source]¶

Gets watershed lines locations from segmented probability density function.

Parameters

  • seg_pdf – numpy.array(dtype=int), shape = [m, 1], An array which contains segment labels for each point in the provided pdf.

  • x – numpy.array(dtype=int), shape = [m, 1], An array that represents the x axis. (seg_pdf represents the y axis)

Return gates

list, a list with its entries as the boundaries of each gate

src.cyto.segmentation.merge(seg_pdf)[source]¶

Assign each point in segments of seg_pdf that has been suppressed (i.e. zeroed) to the closest segment.

Parameters

seg_pdf – numpy.array(dtype=int), shape = [m, 1], An array which contains segment labels for each point in pdf.

Returns

numpy.array(dtype=int), shape = [m, 1], An array which contains newly assigned segment labels.

src.cyto.segmentation.non_maximum_suppression(pdf, seg_pdf, area_threshold=0.01)[source]¶

Performs non-maximum suppression on segments that do not surpass the provided area-under-the-curve (AUC) threshold.

Parameters

  • pdf – numpy.array(dtype=int), shape = [m, 1], An array which represents probability density function.

  • seg_pdf – numpy.array(dtype=int), shape = [m, 1], An array which contains segment labels for each point in the provided pdf.

  • area_threshold – float: the minimum allowed AUC (ratio of cells) to be considered a proper segment/gate.

Returns

numpy.array(dtype=int), shape = [m, 1], masked segments with zeros in place of the original suppressed segments.

src.cyto.segmentation.segment_func(z, method='water', x=None, pdf=None, area_threshold=0.005, width_threshold=0.2, depth_threshold=0.2, num_segments=2, verbose=True)[source]¶

This method performs segmentation on a raw vector of cells.

Parameters

  • z – numpy.array(dtype=float), shape = [n, 1], An array which contains original data (cells).

  • method – str: defines segmentation method, [‘watershed’, ‘otsu’, ‘jenkis’].

  • x – numpy.array(dtype=int), shape = [m, 1], An array that represents the x axis where pdf represents the y axis. (Only required for watershed segmentation.)

  • pdf – numpy.array(dtype=int), shape = [m, 1], An array which represents the probability density function. (Only required for watershed segmentation.)

  • area_threshold – float: the minimum allowed AUC (ratio of cells) to be considered a proper segment/gate. (Only required for watershed segmentation.)

  • width_threshold – float: the minimum allowed width of the ravine between two segments/gates for the later to be considered a separate segment or an extension of the previous segment. Only required for watershed segmentation.

  • depth_threshold – float: the minimum allowed depth of the ravine between two segments/gates for the later to be considered a separate segment or an extension of the previous segment. Only required for watershed segmentation.

  • num_segments – int: number of segments. Only required for Otsu and Jenkis.

  • verbose – Bool, if true, prints each gate area, width and depth values and whether they are suppressed or not.

Returns

  • watershed_lines - list, len(bounds) = m+1.

src.cyto.segmentation.suppress_and_merge_tiny_basins(pdf, seg_pdf, width_threshold, depth_threshold, verbose=True)[source]¶

Suppresses and merges tiny basins/gates/segments depending on the width and depth of the ravine between them.

Parameters

  • pdf – numpy.array(dtype=int), shape = [m, 1], An array which represents probability density function.

  • seg_pdf – numpy.array(dtype=int), shape = [m, 1], An array which contains segment labels for each point in the provided pdf.

  • width_threshold – float: the minimum allowed width of the ravine between two segments/gates for the later to be considered a separate segment or an extension of the previous segment.

  • depth_threshold – float: the minimum allowed depth of the ravine between two segments/gates for the later to be considered a separate segment or an extension of the previous segment.

  • verbose – Bool, if true, prints width and depth values and whether they are suppressed or not.

Returns

numpy.array(dtype=int), shape = [m, 1], An array which contains newly assigned segment labels.

src.cyto.segmentation.tighten_all_gates(z, gates, gate_q_factor=0.01)[source]¶

Tightens all gates location based on the provided quantile.

Parameters

  • z – numpy.array(dtype=float), shape = [n, 1], An array which contains original data (cells).

  • gates – list, len(gates) = m where m is the number of gates.

  • gate_q_factor – float, tightening the gates using quantiles.

Returns

modified_gates list, len(gates) = m where m is the number of gates.
